caption: Table 1: Classification accuracy (%) on the six datasets. DLC is for domain label classification. TLC-DF is for class label classification from domain features. TLC-EEG is for end-to-end class label classification. TLC-EEG-woDO is for class label classification direct from EEG when samples in the training set and test set are from different domains.
description: This table presents the classification accuracy results obtained from six different datasets (WM-CVPR, WM-DEAP, WM-KUL, SK-CVPR, SK-DEAP, and SK-KUL).  It compares the performance of four different classification methods: domain label classification (DLC), class label classification using domain features (TLC-DF), end-to-end class label classification using EEG signals (TLC-EEG), and end-to-end class label classification where training and testing sets come from different domains (TLC-EEG-woDO). Chance levels for each classification task are also included for reference.

caption: Table 2: Zero-shot EEG classification accuracy (%) on WM-CVPR and SK-CVPR datasets.
description: This table presents the results of zero-shot EEG classification experiments conducted on the WM-CVPR and SK-CVPR datasets.  Zero-shot learning refers to a scenario where the model is tested on classes unseen during training. The table shows the accuracy (Accnear) of classifying test samples into temporally adjacent classes and the accuracy (Acc7th) of classifying test samples into the seventh closest class.  This demonstrates the model's tendency to rely on temporal autocorrelation features rather than genuine class-related features when presented with novel classes.

caption: Table 3: Accuracy (%) for joint training on WM-CVPR and SK-CVPR with a loss function of cosine similarity (CS) or InfoNCE.
description: This table presents the accuracy of the retrieval task in the EEG-image joint training.  It shows the Top1 accuracy, Top5 accuracy, and Rank accuracy for both WM-CVPR and SK-CVPR datasets, using both cosine similarity (CS) loss and InfoNCE loss functions. The chance level is also included for comparison.

caption: Table 4: Accuracy (%) for semantic correctness. The repeated times N was set to 50.
description: This table presents the accuracy of semantic correctness for image generation experiments.  The accuracy is measured using n-way top-k accuracy, where n is the number of image classes (50 and 100 in this case), and k indicates the top k predictions. The results are shown for the WM-CVPR and SK-CVPR datasets and compared to the chance level.  The experiment was repeated 50 times (N=50).

caption: Table 5: Decoding accuracy (%) for the six datasets on training, validation and test set. Leave-subjects-out data splitting strategy is used for training and test data. Leave-samples-out and leave-subjects-out data splitting strategy is used for training and validation set. The mean accuracy and standard deviation are calculated over subjects level with a five-fold cross-validation.
description: This table presents the decoding accuracy for six datasets (WM-CVPR, WM-DEAP, WM-KUL, SK-CVPR, SK-DEAP, and SK-KUL) using two data splitting strategies: leave-samples-out and leave-subjects-out.  The results are shown for the training, validation, and test sets. The chance level is also indicated for each dataset.

caption: Table 6: Decoding accuracy (%) using different EEG bands for domain label classification (DLC-EEG)
description: This table presents the decoding accuracy for domain label classification using different EEG frequency bands (delta, theta, alpha, beta, low gamma, and high gamma).  The accuracy is shown for six datasets created by applying different experimental designs to both Watermelon and SparrKULee EEG data.  The chance level is also shown for comparison.

caption: Table 7: Decoding accuracy (%) using different EEG bands for class label classification from domain features (TLC-DF)
description: This table presents the decoding accuracy for class label classification from domain features (TLC-DF) using different EEG frequency bands (Delta, Theta, Alpha, Beta, Low gamma, High gamma). The results are shown for six datasets: WM-CVPR, WM-DEAP, WM-KUL, SK-CVPR, SK-DEAP, and SK-KUL.  Each dataset represents a specific EEG decoding task reorganized using a different experimental paradigm (CVPR, DEAP, KUL). The table highlights how the decoding accuracy varies across different frequency bands and datasets, illustrating the influence of domain features across various experimental setups and frequency ranges.

caption: Table 8: Decoding accuracy (%) using different EEG bands for class label classification directly from EEG (TLC-EEG)
description: This table presents the decoding accuracy for class label classification directly from EEG data using different frequency bands (delta, theta, alpha, beta, low gamma, high gamma).  The results are shown for six datasets, each created by applying a different experimental paradigm (CVPR, DEAP, KUL) to both human EEG data and watermelon EEG data. Chance level accuracy is also provided for each dataset. This table helps demonstrate that even when removing low-frequency components to eliminate baseline drift, the high decoding accuracies are still observed because models rely on domain features rather than class-related features.

caption: Table 7: Decoding accuracy (%) using different EEG bands for class label classification from domain features (TLC-DF)
description: This table presents the decoding accuracy for class label classification using domain features.  The accuracies are shown for six different datasets (WM-CVPR, WM-DEAP, WM-KUL, SK-CVPR, SK-DEAP, SK-KUL) across various frequency bands (delta, theta, alpha, beta, low gamma, high gamma, and full-band).  The chance level for each dataset is also included for comparison. The table helps to understand how different frequency components of EEG signal contribute to the accuracy of class label decoding from the domain features.
